home.description:
welcome
My name is Suzanne, I'm a developer and artist.
This is a space I created to showcase the things I've been working on. Have a look around!

about.description:
about me
Hi! My name is Suzanne, I'm a sophomore pursuing a BSE in Digital Media Design at the University of Pennsylvania. I like programming, art, 3D modeling, listening to Beach House, and making music videos. In my work, I hope to combine computer science, art, and music in a way that sheds light on my own mixed identity.

links to stuff

  • Music xx Music visualization app I made in Spring 2016
  • Bottle of Suze Etsy shop My Etsy shop - originally designed shirts & prints
  • (Wo)man Up Public installation piece another student and I made concerning gender inequality
  • Project Inspiration: Portraiture A project I did on portraiture in writing, visual art, and music
  • Don't Go with the Crowd Art History paper/blog post I wrote about crowd portrayal in art

    • contact me here
    sknop@seas.upenn.edu

    about this site
    This website was completely built and designed by me. It is named after La bouteille de Suze, 1912, a Picasso still life. All the work shown is my own, or part of a team project with which I was a major part of. Enjoy!

content.project-description:
PennApps XIV (Fall 2016) submission

OHQ, or Office Hours Queue, is a web app with the goal to streamline the office hours process by adding transparency through informative and intuitive interface. I built OHQ in a team of 3, working on both the frontend and the backend. OHQ was built using JavaScript, Firebase, Require.js, HTML, CSS, and Bootstrap.

Try it out here!
View the source code here.

Sept 9-11, 2016

project content.description: Dorothy and me at the start of PennApps (2/3 of our team)

content.project-blurb: investigation of subliminal eyetracking for VR applications
content.project-description:
During the summer of 2016, I worked on a VR research project with another student under Dr. Stephen Lane at the University of Pennsylvania. The project objective was to draw conclusions about sublimal eye movements in virtual reality environments that could ultimately be used in industry to enhance gameplay control. We used an Oculus Rift specially fitted with an SMI EyeTracker to conduct tests. Test "games" were created in Unity, and Processing was used for data visualization.

May-August 2016

project content.description: The Oculus Rift retrofitted with an SMI EyeTracker, which we used to track the user's gaze during tests.
Presenting the project at the CURF Research Expo

Graph of stimuli: angle spawned v. angle killed. Higher spawn angles indicate stimuli farther out in the perephery, and higher kill angles mean the stimuli disappear more quickly. Our focus for this iteration of tests was the blue dots, or the instances in which the user looked at the stimulus but did not indicate that they saw the stimulus (via pressing a keyboard button).

A heatmap of the user's gaze during an earlier phase of testing. White, is the user's gaze, red is the point which the user was told to focus on, blue are the stimuli shown in the periphery of the user's vision. Yellow squares appear in the bottom left whenever the user presses a button to indicate they saw the stimulus. This application was written in Java using Processing.

content.project-description:
This site is a complete revamp of an old personal website I had written in 2013. After learning way more Javascript during my freshmen year at Penn, I wrote this in July/August of 2016. Both content (via JSON parsing) and templating (via Backbone) are much more modifiable this time!

What I used: Javascript/HTML/CSS, jQuery, Backbone, Handlebars, fancyBox, Bootstrap

Source code here

Created summer 2016

project content.description: project menu example (hovering on st. vincent)

content.project-blurb: a javascript music visualization web app
content.project-description:
This is a music visual accompaniment application that combines music, you, and your memories i.e. music x you x environment: Music xx. When I listen to music from my past, I often think of my surroundings at the time I first listened to that music. The goal of Music xx is to enrich the music listening/reminiscing experience.

This was the final project for the Javascript course I took in Spring 2015.

What I used: Spotify API, ThreeJS, Backbone, Handlebars

Try it out here!

content.project-blurb: cooking web game using Makey Makey
content.project-description:
This was my team's entry for Penn Play 2016, University of Pennsylvania's gaming hackathon! The theme was time, so we obviously had to make our game about thyme. The point of the game is to chop the thyme before the time runs out. We used a Makey Makey to turn a real cutting board with foil wrapped around it into part of the game, so the user could actually chop the cutting board with a metal knife identical to the one in the game.

What we used: Javascript, Autodesk Maya, Makey Makey keyboard, puns

Try it out here! (chop with spacebar)

content.project-blurb: handdrawn animated music video for "100 Million" by Charlie Hilton
Nan trying to figure out what to do with her life!

content.project-description:
The starting point idea for this gif was inspired by the song "Rainy Days" by Late Night Alumni, which actually takes most of its lyrics from the poem "The Rainy Day" by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. The gif is about that old childhood feeling of having created something great, only to discover that the idea isn't novel or great at all. The lyric "the day is cold and dark and dreary" stuck out to me, so this is the initial mood of the girl in the gif. The mood is temporarily overcome by her great idea, but afterwards she finds herself once again in the cold, dark, and dreary state she was in before.

Created Fall 2015

sketches.description: I love sketching! I sketch all the time and I really, really value the importance of it. Here are just a few pages from some of my past sketchbooks - check back soon for updates with more recent stuff!

content.project-blurb: Etsy shop that sells original design tshirts and prints
content.project-description:
The Bottle of Suze Etsy shop is a project I started in Spring of 2015, an offshoot of my Project Inspiration portraiture project. The idea for the shop came when I was browsing the internet for a cool tshirt to buy, but couldn't find any that aligned with my interests. I decided to just design my own and put them on Etsy for anyone else who also wanted them. I carried on with the project independent of PI, and I still continue to make and sell shirts and prints.

Visit the shop here!

content.project-blurb: Images, Words, Music: A Portrait of the World
content.project-description: Project Inspiration is a self-directed project stemming from a source of inspiration (in this case, the novel Orlando by Virginia Woolf), and carried out to create or learn something meaningful. After reading Orlando I was struck by how Woolf had expertly portrayed the heroic, androgynous, satirical protagonist, Orlando. I thought a lot about how the essence of a good portrait is universal to any media. I studied the portraiture of people in art by painting and illustrating, and I explored the portraiture of environments with a combination of video and music. This project exposed me to many interests I probably would not have delved into otherwise! (i.e. portrait painting, video making, Virginia Woolf, and more of an offshoot, tshirt design)

project content.description: I made this video as a collage of different clips, thoughts, and music as a way to express what I learned about the beauty of portraiture from reading Orlando and from trying to look at the world with portraiture in mind.
Portrait of Virginia Woolf, author of Orlando, and the inspiration for this portraiture project
Portrait of Ezra Pound, a poet I admire for his Imagist poems
A self portrait I completed under this project.

Portraits of artists, later used as a tshirt/print design in my Etsy shop. An important aspect of my project was the blending of different media (writing, visual art, video, music) towards one expressional goal. So, artists were as important as writers.
Portraits of writers - design used for tshirt on the Bottle of Suze Etsy shop

content.project-blurb: Public installation to bring attention to gender inequality in the workforce
content.project-description:
Initially envisioned to address gender inequality specifically in the tech industry, my project partner and I realized that this problem extends to women in all career paths. We installed two foam door frames for a day on Locust Walk, a central location on campus. On top of the doors is written "HAVING TROUBLE? TRY BEING A WOMAN". The door for women is occluded by tape, making it harder to pass through and representing the barriers women must overcome before being on the same level as men. Penn's frequently toxic pre-professional atmosphere made this installation even more impactful. Many students stopped to take pictures and read the sign, and some walked through.

December 2015

project content.description: Me and my project partner, Camille
